{{Infobox Book | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = Yellow Tapers for Paris | title_orig = | translator = | image = [[File:Yellow_tapers.jpg|200px]]<!-- prefer 1st edition cover --> | image_caption = Dustjacket of 1946 American edition | author = [[Bruce Marshall]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[Scotland]] | language = [[English language|English]] | series = | genre = [[Novel]] | publisher = | pub_date = 1943 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print ([[Hardback]]) | pages = 294 | isbn = N/A | preceded_by = [[Delilah Upside Down, a Tract, with a Thrill]] (1941) | followed_by = [[The World, the Flesh, and Father Smith]] (1944) }} '''''Yellow Tapers for Paris''''' is a 1943 novel by Scottish writer [[Bruce Marshall]].
==Plot summary == The crushing 1940 defeat of France (an event the author lived through) is the subject of this novel. Marshall implies that France lost its soul and was itself more responsible for its defeat than Germany.
We meet Bigou, the protagonist, in 1934. He is an honest, hard-working, but irreligious and immoral [[accountant]], employed by a successful industrial firm in Paris. He is mildly troubled that his firm expends considerable effort conniving to avoid paying its legitimate [[taxes]]. Conversations with accountants and employees of other companies lead Bigou to realize that most of the business enterprises of the time in [[France]] are behaving similarly,
The novel gives us a picture of Bigouâs life. The reader is introduced to his family, sulky, plucky daughter Odette and sickly wife Marie, friends, his coworkers and other people he meets in his business life. The author endeavors to show that money and pleasure were the main goals sought with any sincerity. Even religion, when it did exist, wasnât much more than an outward display. Bigou does come to believe that the local priest is one of the few people he knows who exhibits integrity.
The âpetit bourgeoisâ in the novel are shabby and bewildered as they assist helplessly at their nationâs funeral, but they stand in brilliant contrast to the insatiable greed and craftiness of the wealthy.
Marshall clearly believes that France lost its virtue, especially among its elites. He even implies that the leaders of the Church were more interested in status and materialism than spirituality. The novel indicates that the common people, deprived of the just rewards of their labor, and without worthy spiritual direction, became trapped in immorality, and were spiritually and physically impoverished.<ref>Marshall, B: ''Yellow Tapers for Paris'' New York: Doubleday & Co. 1943.</ref><ref>Jackson, Katherine Gauss ''Books In Brief'' Harpers, December 1946</ref>

The stories cover the leadup to the [[Battle of France|Nazi Invasion]] and its immediate aftermath, but the events of the respective stories are much different. Marshall's ends before the [[Military occupation|occupation]], while NÃ©mirovsky's has significant portions devoted to it. Both works have major characters who work in the financial fieldâMarshall's [[protagonist]] is a financial [[accountant]] while NÃ©mirovsky's work has major characters who work for a [[bank]].
Both books were written during and/or immediately after the actual period itself, but show considerable reflectionâthey aren't just "[[diary]]" entries. Even more remarkable considering the activities of the authors at the timeâNÃ©mirovsky struggling to evade the [[Nazis]] and protect her two [[daughters]] and Marshall working for the [[British Army]].
There are also remarkable parallels in the two writers' lives.
They were close in age, Marshall was born in 1899 and NÃ©mirovsky in 1903.
Both were converts to [[Catholicism]].
Both [[authors]] were parents of similar aged daughtersâthe birthdate of Marshall's daughter, Sheila, is not available, but her husband was born in 1927. One would assume that she was close to the same age as NÃ©mirovsky's oldest daughter, Denise, who was born in 1929.
Both [[writers]] were [[expatriates]] living in [[Paris]] at the same time (sometime in the early 1920s until the [[Nazi]] [[invasion]]). Both were successful writers, and lived in a place, [[Paris]], during a time when writers were greatly celebrated -- "[[Lost Generation|The Lost Generation]]." It's not hard to imagine that one or both of them could have crossed paths with some of the literary notables living there during that period ([[Henry Miller]], [[Ernest Hemingway]], [[Ford Madox Ford]], [[Lytton Strachey]], [[Edith Sitwell]], [[F. Scott Fitzgerald]], [[T. S. Eliot]], [[Ezra Pound]], [[Edith Wharton]], [[Gertrude Stein]], etc.). However, there is no evidence that NÃ©mirovsky and Marshall ever met.
Marshall worked for a financial accounting firm while NÃ©mirovsky's family was in banking.
Both were well-established and prolific [[novelists]] at the time of the invasionâNÃ©mirovsky's first [[novel]] was published in 1927, and she had published about 14 novels by 1940. Marshall's first was in 1924 and he had published about 15 novels by 1940.
Both fled the [[Battle of France|Nazi invasion]] and wrote novels partly based on those experiences.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/books/authors/nemirovskyirene/suitefrancaise |title=Suite Francaise by Irene Nemirovsky: Reviews |accessdate=2008-02-15 |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080201023759/http://www.metacritic.com/books/authors/nemirovskyirene/suitefrancaise <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-02-01}}</ref>
